Project Description  The Project will help (i) reduce water pollution; (ii) protect water 
resources; (iii) promote sustainable economic development; and 
(iv) improve the environment, living conditions, and public health 
standards in four cities of Hebei Province. The Project has five 
components  to  provide  improved  wastewater  collection  and 
treatment in Baoding, Chengde, Tangshan, and Zhangjiakou. The 
Project  will  also  involve  capacity  building  and  training  for  the 
Hebei provincial government and municipal sewerage companies 
(MSCs). 
   
Rationale  The Hai River Basin is the fifth largest river basin in the PRC and 
intersects four provinces and two provincial cities. Hebei Province 
lies entirely within the basin, which has 120 million people, 65 
million of whom live in Hebei. It contributes about one third of the 
wastewater flow and pollution load. As a result of rapid economic 
growth and urbanization, water pollution and water scarcity have 
become major problems. The Project will significantly help control 
water pollution in Hebei and the Hai River Basin.  The Project is 
the major urban infrastructure initiative under Hebei’s 10th Five-
Year  Plan  (2001-2005).  The  proposed  wastewater  treatment 
plants and associated sewage collection and disposal systems in 
Hebei  cities  were  identified  as  high-priority  immediate-
improvement  projects  in  the  ADB-assisted  Hai  River  Basin 
Pollution Prevention and Control Plan.  
 
Objectives and Scope  The project objectives are to enhance the urban environment and 
public  health  through  better  wastewater  management,  and  to 
improve the quality of surface- and groundwater resources in and 
downstream of the project cities. Related objectives include (i) 
creating  MSCs  and  making  them  efficient  and  commercially 
managed;  (ii)  supporting  integrated  approaches  to  basin-wide 
pollution prevention and control; and (iii) improving cost recovery 
from  users  through  an  improved  tariff  structure,  with  gradual 
increases to achieve full cost recovery. 
   
Cost Estimates  The total  project cost is $165.34 million equivalent, including a 
foreign exchange cost of $82.36 (49.8%) and a local currency cost 
of $82.98 million (50.2%) equivalent.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People's Republic of China (PRC) for the Hebei Province Wastewater Management 
Project. 
 
2.  The Project is in Hebei Province, northern PRC, which has an area of 188,000 square 
kilometers and a population of 65 million. The province lies in the heavily polluted Hai River 
Basin (HRB) which drains into Bohai Bay through nine tributaries. The Project is one of a 
number of planned wastewater management projects under the Hai River Basin Pollution 
Prevention and Control Plan (HRPPCP), funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 This 
basin-wide program comprises more than 400 potential projects, of which the high-priority ones 
are targeted for completion in 2010. The four project cities are priority areas under the plan, and 
the  project  components  have  been  prioritized  for  immediate  implementation  under  the 
HRPPCP. 
 
3.  During the 2002 Country Programming Mission, the Government reconfirmed its request 
for assistance for the Project. In 2000, ADB provided technical assistance (TA) to help the 
Hebei provincial government formulate the Project.2 Following completion of the TA study in 
August 2001, the Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC in November 2001, and the follow-up 
Fact-Finding Mission in March 2002 to discuss the Project with the central and provincial 
governments. The Government approved a feasibility study prepared by the Hebei provincial 
government on 7 November 2002. Loan negotiations with authorized representatives of the 
central Government were conducted in Manila from 18 to 22 November 2002. The Project was 
formulated based on the findings of the ADB missions, information provided by the Government, 
beneficiary consultations, discussions with other funding agencies, and recommendations of the 
feasibility study and TA consultants. The project framework outlines the goal, purpose, outputs, 
and inputs or activities (Appendix 1).  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
4.  Since the 1980s, water has rapidly become scarcer for industrial use and domestic 
consumption, especially in northern PRC, creating severe economic losses. Many rivers in this 
region are dry for 5–8 months a year, which has serious  implications for water resource 
management in the basin. In the HRB, the demand for water (50 billion cubic meters [m3] per 
year) exceeded supply (33.9 billion m3) by 16.1 billion m3 in 2000.  
 
5.  Increasing  reliance  on  groundwater  to  compensate  for  surface  water  scarcity  has 
compromised future sustainable use of the resource. Water supplies are so dependent on 
ground water resources that limiting extraction will dramatically increase water shortages. In the 
HRB, estimates of sustainable groundwater supply are in the order of 17.3 billion m3 while 1998 
withdrawals were 26.1 billion m3, indicating that overextraction is as high as 8.8 billion m3 every 
year. As a result, deep and shallow groundwater tables have dropped 90 and 50 meters, 
respectively, on the Hai plains. Other side effects of unsustainable exploitation include salinity 
intrusion and ground subsidence.

6.  Surface and groundwater pollution now represent a huge problem not only for the 
environment but also for public health, especially since water is so scarce in northern PRC. 
Over 65% of river length in the HRB is classified as highly polluted and has no beneficial use. 
Major  groups  of  polluters  include  industrial  and  municipal  wastewater  and  other  nonpoint 
sources. 
 
7.  During the 1990s, industrial wastewater flows and loads declined significantly while 
municipal flows and loads increased. In 1999, municipal wastewater flows (20.3 billion m3) and 
chemical oxygen demand loads (7.0 million tons) exceeded total industrial flows (19.7 billion m3) 
and loads (6.9 million tons) for the first time. These trends are likely to continue. Industries 
gradually decreased their wastewater flows and loads through wastewater pretreatment, internal 
reuse of process water, and use of cleaner technology. However, the performance of municipal 
wastewater management is generally poor: wastewater treatment rates are far lower than 
industrial rates, treatment capacities are frequently underutilized, and treatment efficiency is 
often low.  
 
8.  As in industrialized countries, pollution from urban municipal wastewater in the PRC is 
managed  through  updated  municipal  sewerage  systems,  including  collection  sewers  and 
treatment plants designed to receive industrial wastewater, resulting in large savings because of 
economy of scale of treatment to remove degradable organics.3 The treated municipal effluent is 
reused for irrigation and industries. The municipal systems also provide on-site excreta disposal 
units for homes and buildings not connected to municipal sewers. A new challenge is to 
establish or extend a permit system whereby municipal governments can control wastewater 
discharges from industries, including monitoring and enforcement of their performance.  
 
9.  To cope with increasing  demand for updated municipal sewerage systems, in 1991–
1999 construction of wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) increased dramatically from 87 to 
398, and total capacity from 4.7 million to 15.8 million m3 per day. Despite the tremendous 
increase in municipal wastewater treatment capacity over the last decade, most cities continue 
to be underserved by sewers and wastewater treatment plants. In 2000, only 7.5 billion m3 (34% 
of the total discharges) of municipal wastewater were estimated to have received secondary 
treatment. This is a significant improvement on the 4% rate achieved in 1991, but backlog is still 
enormous. Municipal water demand projections show that municipal wastewater treatment 
capacity will have to be nearly quadrupled over the next 20 years just to maintain its level of 
service.  
 
10.  During the 1990s, most water pollution was caused by industries. While great progress 
has been made in reducing pollution, municipal wastewater management has lagged behind 
largely because financial and institutional constraints hinder city governments from keeping up 
with rapid urban growth. An important regulatory measure for industrial pollution control during 
the Ninth Five-Year Plan (9th FYP) (1996-2000) was to request urban industries to treat their 
wastewater  to  national  wastewater  discharge  standards  by  31  December  2000.  The  key 
operational policy for urban wastewater management included the requirement that by 2010, 
wastewater treatment rate in all cities should not be lower than 60%, and not lower than 70% for 
major cities4 with secondary treatment facilities.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
11.  The acute water shortage in northern PRC will soon become unmanageable unless 
much more significant, comprehensive, and decisive measures are taken. Recognizing that the 
lack of water seriously limits economic and social development, the Government gives high 
priority to water resource management. While augmenting supply will partly solve the water 
shortage,5 preconditions for success are proper management of groundwater, water pollution 
prevention and control, and wastewater reuse.  
 
12.  Water pollution will continue to be a critical problem over the next decade. Rivers, lakes, 
and groundwater are expected to deteriorate in many areas, particularly in the water-short north. 
The challenge will be to maintain the momentum of industrial pollution control and broaden the 
attack to cover growing problems of municipal wastewater discharges and nonpoint sources. 
The issues are complex and the institutions influencing the pace and nature of development 
numerous. Any strategy to solve municipal water pollution must create a firm and sustainable 
financial basis to operate municipal wastewater services. A key element is adequate pricing of 
wastewater services.  
 
13.  The Government’s ongoing economic and enterprise reform programs require that all 
wastewater and water supply projects be financially sustainable and capable of cost recovery. 
Hebei is a priority area for tariff reform.  ADB has supported the water tariff reform process 
through several TA projects.6 A study on wastewater tariff is helping the Government develop 
national wastewater tariff guidelines.  
 
14.  The  Government  has  significantly  increased  funding  to  build  basic  sewerage 
infrastructure  to  meet  the  challenge  of  increased  urbanization.  Total  investment  in  water 
pollution control has increased by 48% in nominal terms, from CNY182 billion during the 9th 
FYP to CNY270 billion during the 10th FYP (2001-2005). Capital investment to meet demand 
for  wastewater  services  will  be  enormous,  and  private  sector  participation  will  likely  be 
necessary to help bridge the financing gap. However, private sector participation will not be 
feasible unless service charges are raised to financially viable levels. 
 
15.  Nonpoint water pollution due to fertilizer runoff, pesticide runoff, and discharges from 
intensive animal production is worsening. Nonpoint sources of nutrients are significant sources 
of eutrophication, which is occurring in many lakes throughout the PRC and also in shallow 
near-shore marine areas that experience limited tidal flushing. Bohai Bay is susceptible to 
eutrophication as indicated by the frequent occurrence of red tides. The 2002 country strategy 
and program includes assistance from ADB to address nonpoint water pollution control at a 
policy level.7  
 
16.  To clean up the most polluted river basins, the Government uses an integrated basin-
wide wastewater management approach, which has many advantages, including effective and 
sustainable water resource development and management.  The Government designated the

19.  Cost recovery has been promoted through policy dialogue on tariff increases and the 
introduction of commercial management principles. These measures have helped demonstrate 
that such projects can be financially viable under the lending terms of ADB’s ordinary capital

20.  Since 1988, ADB has financed 48 TA studies for $32.6 million to solve problems in water

assistance has resulted in rational pricing of water, major increases in water tariffs, introduction 
of  wastewater  tariffs,  implementation  of  commercial  principles,  improved  environmental

introduction of private sector participation. These improvements are fundamental to make the 
water and wastewater sectors financially and operationally sustainable.  
 
21.  ADB has led in promoting private sector participation in the PRC’s water supply sector. 
Following the TA to help the Government prepare the first pilot build-operate-transfer water

23.  Experience  in  wastewater  and  water  resource  management  in  the  PRC,  although 
limited, indicates that projects are well implemented and that water and wastewater tariffs are 
increased as required. Analysis indicates that consumers are willing to pay substantially higher 
prices  for  reliable  supply  of  good-quality  water  and,  to  a  certain  extent,  for  wastewater 
treatment. Issues related to tariff levels, cost recovery, and commercial orientation of the water 
utilities were carefully addressed during project processing. Lessons learned from the previous 
projects were reflected in the project design, including thorough review of technical designs and 
technologies, rigorous financial and economic analysis, social assessment, and institutional-
strengthening measures to improve corporate governance. 
 
24.  ADB’s three strategic objectives for the PRC are to (i) improve economic efficiency, (ii) 
promote growth to reduce poverty in poor interior provinces, and (iii)  enhance environmental 
protection and natural resource management. Wastewater treatment can contribute to all these. 
Proper management of wastewater is essential to raise the living standards and productivity of 
urban populations, protect water resources, and sustain economic growth. In the wastewater 
sector, ADB focuses on (i) improving wastewater services through investment in physical 
infrastructure, (ii) promoting improved corporate governance and commercial management to 
enhance the potential for future private sector involvement, (iii) improving cost recovery by 
strengthening tariff systems and structures for wastewater to ensure sustainability and attract 
private  participation,  and  (iv)  ensuring  water  resource  conservation  and  environmental 
protection through legislative and regulatory provisions.  
 
25.  In support of the strategy, the agenda for policy dialogue in the wastewater sector has 
covered key areas of basin-wide pollution prevention and control, industrial and municipal 
wastewater management, enterprise reform and corporate governance, cost recovery and tariff 
reform, and private sector participation. These are highlighted as special features of the Project 
(paras. 33–38) and detailed in Appendix 4. The Project will improve the quality of rivers, lakes, 
and  groundwater  in  and  downstream  from  the  project  cities  by  collecting  and  treating 
wastewater generated. The Project is consistent with ADB’s country operational strategy. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives  
26.  The objectives of the Project are to improve the urban environment and public health 
through  improved  wastewater  management,  and  to  improve  the  quality  of  surface-  and 
groundwater in and downstream from the project cities. Related objectives include (i) creating 
municipal sewerage companies (MSCs) and making them efficient and commercially managed; 
(ii) supporting comprehensive approaches to river basin-wide pollution prevention and control; 
and (iii) improving cost recovery from users through improved tariffs, with gradual increases to 
achieve full cost recovery.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
27.  The Project has five components, consisting of improved wastewater collection and 
treatment systems in the four project cities. Project outputs include (i) WWTPs that would treat

1.  Part A: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Baoding 
 
28.  Part A will serve the urban districts of Baoding, the largest project city with 718,000 
people in 2000, expected to increase to 870,000 in 2010. Facilities include 97 km of sewers, two 
submersible-pump lift stations, and a WWTP expansion of 160,000 m3/day. The city has two 
WWTPs, each with a capacity of 80,000 m3/day; the downstream plant, Yingdingzhuang, is to 
be expanded under the Project. The existing collection system was developed piecemeal and 
has many deficiencies related to inadequate ground cover, adverse slope, and inappropriate 
routing of sewers. Major portions of the collection system are to be rebuilt under the Project. 
Industrial wastewater is about half the total flow. Wastewater treatment will improve water 
quality in the downstream Baiyangdian lakes, which collectively form the largest lake in the 
northern China plain and have great potential for tourism and improved fisheries. 
 
  2.  Part B: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Chengde 
 
29.  Part B will serve the city proper of Chengde, whose population is expected to grow from 
250,000 in 2000 to 325,000 in 2010. Facilities include 32 km of sewers and a WWTP with a 
capacity of 80,000 m3/day. Chengde relies on tourism related to the former imperial summer 
palace and adjacent temples, and has developed a workable separate sewer system to protect 
water quality in ponds created behind inflatable dams on the Wulie River, which runs through 
the city center. The downstream portion of the Wulie is heavily polluted by raw sewage from two 
major outfalls of the city, while pollution of the downstream Luan River affects the Panda 
reservoirs, which are raw water sources for Tianjin’s potable water supply. The industrial 
wastewater component is only 20% of the total. The status of Chengde as an environmentally 
responsible prefecture-level municipality and as a tourism center will be at risk until it acquires 
wastewater treatment facilities. 
 
3.  Part C: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Tangshan New District 
 
30.  Part C will serve a portion of Tangshan, about 15 km from the city center, consisting of 
the New District and the urbanized portion of Fengrun County; the population is expected to 
increase from 180,000 in 2000 to 225,000 in 2010. The New District is on the coastal plain near 
the Hebei border with Tianjin. The facilities include 10 km of sewers and a WWTP with a 
capacity of 80,000 m3/day. The new facilities are adjacent to the 32,000 m3/day New District 
plant, which is heavily overloaded and will be rehabilitated under the Project. The service area 
contains a modern, economically competitive industrial park, and industries generate 70% of 
total wastewater. In the absence of an expanded municipal treatment plant, the industries are 
faced with very high costs for advanced on-site wastewater treatment to meet surface water 
discharge  standards.  The  Huanxiang  River  flows  through  the  city  and  provides  water  for 
downstream municipalities, and agriculture. The river is heavily polluted by discharges of raw 
sewage and partly treated wastewater, aggravated by an upstream reservoir that prevents 
dilution from stream flow. Residents and farmers downstream in Tangshan and Tianjin have 
formally complained, and requested improved treatment.

7 
4.  Part D1: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Zhangjiakou  
 
31.  Part D1 will serve Zhangjiakou City proper, whose population of 500,000 in 2000 is 
expected to increase to 632,000 in 2010. The facilities include 40 km of sewers, 5 km of open 
channel, and a WWTP with a capacity of 100,000 m3/day. The city has no municipal wastewater 
treatment, and raw sewage discharges from 400 outlets, heavily polluting the Qingshui River 
that runs through the middle of the city. Farmers divert raw sewage from the river for use in 
irrigation. Half of the wastewater is from industry and, in combination with wastewater from 
Xuanhua, the large pollution loads have polluted and prevented beneficial use of Beijing’s 
Guanting Reservoir as a standby drinking water source, which lies downstream on the Yang 
River.  
 
5.  Part D2: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Xuanhua 
 
32.  Part  D2  will  serve  Xuanhua,  an  industrial  urban  district  of  Zhangjiakou,  30  km 
downstream on flat terrain adjacent to the Yang River. The population of 235,000 in 2000 is 
expected to grow to 300,000 in 2010. The facilities include 31 km of sewers and a WWTP with a 
capacity of 120,000 m3/day. The area has no municipal wastewater treatment. About 80% of the 
wastewater is from industry, including a major steel mill, large brewery, fertilizer plant, and 
paper mill. Heavy-metal pollution over many years from poorly treated or pretreated industrial 
discharges has prevented beneficial use of the downstream Guanting Reservoir, which is 
intended to become Beijing’s standby water supply source. The municipal treatment plant is 
urgently  needed  as  a  cost-effective  alternative  to  advanced  on-site  industrial  wastewater 
treatment  at  many  small  plants.  (For  example,  the  steel  mill  has  19  pretreatment  plants 
scattered over half the urban area.) 
 
C.  Special Features 
33.  The Project supports and strengthens several ADB policy initiatives: (i) integrated basin-
wide  pollution  prevention  and  control,  (ii)  improved  wastewater  management  to  create  a 
sustainable  urban  environment,  (iii)  enterprise  reform  and  corporate  governance,  (iv)  cost 
recovery and tariff reform, and (v) private sector participation. A policy framework addressing 
issues and actions required is given in Appendix 4.  
 
34.  The  HRPPCP  provides  a  policy  and  strategic  framework  for  pollution  control  and 
prevention in the HRB. The Project will help the Hebei provincial government implement its 
water quality improvement strategies under the HRPPCP. Interagency cooperation and cross-
jurisdictional programs are vital elements of a basin-wide approach to pollution prevention and 
control. Beijing and Zhangjiakou have discussed protecting Guanting Reservoir and restoring its 
water quality as a standby drinking water source for the capital. Tianjin and the HPG have also 
held a number of meetings on pollution control for the Yuqiao Reservoir, which is the sole 
drinking water source for Tianjin. 
 
35.  A successful wastewater management policy will help prevent and control pollution and 
carry out cost-effective wastewater management and operations. Each project city has urban 
regulations, including on sewer connection approval and supervision. All project cities plan to 
introduce or extend the use of wastewater discharge permits. These permit systems have the 
potential to enhance the regulatory framework to manage industrial wastewater discharge. The 
Project will help MSCs lead in controlling discharge into public sewers.

8  
36.  Transforming MSCs into financially and managerially autonomous enterprises requires a 
sustainable institutional framework for project implementation and future operation. The Project 
will address four aspects of confidence-building enterprise reform and corporate governance: (i) 
structuring MSCs along commercial lines with substantial managerial and financial autonomy, 
(ii) preparing business plans and introducing management information systems, (iii) improving 
the effectiveness of MSC boards of directors, and (iv) strengthening audit arrangements.  
 
37.  The  MSCs  were  established  to  support  the  Government’s  ongoing  economic  and 
enterprise reform programs, and will be strengthened under the relevant laws. Wastewater 
tariffs will be increased to ensure that full cost recovery is achieved by 2008, the first year of 
operation of the new wastewater facilities. The project cities increased wastewater tariffs during 
2000-2002 in anticipation of the Project.  
 
38.  Private  sector  participation  in  the  wastewater  sector  will  provide  a  new  source  of 
financing and thus reduce reliance on government resources. The Project will help create the 
environment  necessary  for  private  sector  participation  by  pursuing  tariff  reform,  full  cost 
recovery, and corporatization, which are the necessary prerequisites for such private sector 
involvement.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Impacts  
61.  The Project will significantly help control water pollution in Hebei Province and the HRB. 
Municipal wastewater treatment is a key element in controlling point-source water pollution, 
which is the first step to meeting stream water quality standards for beneficial water uses. The 
service areas of the project cities contain the major industrial wastewater dischargers. The 
Project will be flexible in imposing pretreatment requirements. The industries in the project cities 
only pretreat discharge to municipal sewers rather than apply the more severe requirements for 
discharge  to  rivers  and  lakes.  The  savings  to  industry,  through  avoidance  of  advanced 
wastewater treatment requirements, will support sustainable economic growth, promote clean 
technologies, and water conservation. To ensure control of industrial wastewater, each project 
city will prepare and submit industrial pollution control plans14 to ADB through the HPMO.  
 
62.  Wastewater interception, treatment, and disposal provide the best long-term prospect for 
controlling water pollution and improving water quality in the rivers and lakes in and downstream 
of the project cities. The WWTPs, which will use the same treatment processes successfully 
used  in  other  treatment  plants,  will  be  cost-effective  and  reliable.15  These  WWTPs  have 
sufficient land to accommodate plant expansion until 2020. Sewer capacities to be installed will 
accommodate growth in wastewater flows until 2020, preventing the risk of sewage overflow in 
the urban service areas. The previous domestic investments in existing overloaded WWTPs and 
partial collection of wastewater will become a fruitful rather than wasted expenditure. The 
Project will also improve land values along urban drainage ditches.  
   
B.  Institutional Benefits  
63.  Each participating city will be provided with consultant advisory services to develop an 
MSC that will (i) be properly constituted, and managerially and financially autonomous; (ii) be 
responsible  for  project  implementation,  working  and  liaising  closely  with  the  various 
departments and agencies of local government; (iii) assume management responsibility for 
future operations and maintenance of project facilities, including responsibility for debt servicing; 
and (iv) assume ownership of all municipal wastewater assets, including all permanent works 
constructed under the Project.  
 
64.  The Project will also help each MSC establish a sound and solid financial management 
system at the beginning of project implementation. The financial management system will be in 
line with ADB's Guidelines for Governance and Financial Management of an ADB Investment 
Project. Each MSC will keep accounts in accordance with commercial accounting principles and 
be subject to independent external audit by a qualified firm of commercial auditors. Accounting 
will be in accordance with relevant PRC accounting standards, which are largely in accordance 
with international norms (para. 53).

D.  Financial Analysis  
72.  The financial internal rate of return is estimated at 5–7% for the project components, or 
better than the 4% weighted average cost of capital in real terms. Tariff increases are required 
to ensure the financial sustainability of the MSCs. The financial evaluation is in Appendix 14.  
 
73.  The sensitivity analyses tested the base case against a cost increase of 10%, revenue 
reduction of 10%, currency devaluation of 30%, and a delay in receiving revenue of 1 year. The 
tests revealed that the components are more sensitive to changes in revenue than cost. The 
sensitivity analysis also examined the risk that certain major industries might not pay for their 
portion of WWTP capacity and associated capacity of trunk sewers, due either to unprofitable 
operations or factory closures. The iron and steel mill in Xuanhua is the most serious risk. If the 
mill defaults on or fails to pay wastewater tariffs, the Zhangjiakou municipal government will 
have to take over the mill’s portion of annual loan repayment. The municipality has the financial 
resources to do so and has provided assurances that it will if needed. Financial records of large 
industries in the project cities and interviews with representatives of industries establish that 
they can expect to be profitable and that the risk of closure is small.  
 
74.  An affordability analysis has been undertaken, based on proposed tariffs and household 
income data from a social survey. Tariffs under the Project are assumed affordable if the 
combined average water and wastewater charges are less than 5% of household income. In all 
the project cities, the estimated tariffs are affordable by the average household and the poorest 
10% of households. The affordability analysis is in  Appendix 14. The proposed tariffs are 
comfortably within the affordability limit in all the project cities.

E.  Economic Analysis 
75.  The economic analysis of the Project is not based on standard benefit-cost analysis, 
since it would not reveal the real economic justification for the Project. The project preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA) feasibility study for the Project did attempt a benefit-cost analysis, 
but with economic internal rates of return of 12–24%. The main motivation for the Project comes 
from a thorough sector analysis of the HRPPCP, which identified and prioritized future sector 
developments. Since the Project aims to help meet the sector development goals, an analysis of 
the project components as independent subprojects will not establish  the real and intended 
economic basis for the Project. The economic analysis of the Project therefore focused on the 
sector development plan, the role of the Project in it, and on the goals—targets for surface-
water quality—to determine whether they are reasonable and will command public support. In 
this case, a least-cost analysis is appropriate: that is, the Project will help the provincial 
government attain sound and clearly established social goals at least cost. Taking the goals as 
given, the economic analysis showed that the Project is designed to meet them at least 
economic cost.  
  
76.  Ample  evidence  exists  that  the  public  supports  water  quality  targets,  but  scientific 
uncertainties limit the assurance that targets will be met. Still, the economic analysis shows that 
the project will minimize the cost of wastewater management, not only at the treatment plants 
but  also  across  the  cities  they  serve.  The  Project  will  achieve  least-cost  wastewater 
management beyond the plant site by including all significant point sources in each plant’s 
service  territory,  and  by  charging  a  wastewater  treatment  tariff  that  will  provide  financial 
incentives to equalize the marginal costs of wastewater management. Appendix 15 discusses 
the economic analysis.18

C.  Institutional Framework:  Laws, Policies, and Government Agencies 
 
5.  The institutional framework for managing surface-water quality in the HRB includes (i) 
legal standards and targets for surface-water quality; and (ii) the policies, regulations, and plans 
to meet the targets. The 1996 Water Pollution and Prevention Law authorized setting national 
standards for surface-water quality and using these standards to set targets for individual 
watercourses. The law empowers the State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA) to 
define technical standards at a national level. 
 
6.  The standards of surface water quality are set according to the intended use of the 
water. Classes I, II, and III apply to surface water for drinking. Classes IV and V are for surface 
water for irrigation or industry. Each class is defined by 30 criteria, prescribing numeric ranges 
for the physical, chemical, and biological properties of water (such as temperature, pH, and 
coliform counts). Once SEPA defined the water quality classes, the desired or targeted ambient 
water quality was determined for each river reach. SEPA set the desired or targeted ambient 
water quality for some strategic river reaches but, more generally, the environmental protection 
department at either the municipal or provincial level set the targeted water quality class. 
 
7.  The plan attain water quality standards in Hebei derives largely from the HRPCPP. After 
SEPA approved the plan in 1999, all the provinces and provincial cities in the HRB obtained 
SEPA endorsement of a pollution-control plan for that part of the HRB within their jurisdiction. 
The Hebei provincial government issued its HRPCPP in July 2000.  Each municipality has 
prepared subordinate local plans. 
 
8.  The HRPCPP does not, by itself, provide a feasible plan to meet the basin’s water 
quality targets since it merely identified potential projects without prioritizing them. To help refine 
the HRPCPP, ADB funded the development of a refined strategic plan, which was completed in 
December 1999. The results of the study included the Immediate Implementation Plan (IIP) and 
the Strategic Basin Management Plan (SBMP). The IIP was developed by assessing and 
prioritizing the HRPPCP projects, resulting in 86 priority projects. The four project cities and 
components were included in the IIP. The SBMP addressed the need for a long-term optimum 
strategy  that  includes  monitoring  and  management  information  systems,  strengthening  of 
regulations and river basin planning and management, identification and implementation of that 
strategy, and monitoring and review of that strategy.

D.  Evaluation of Current Framework, and Needed Reforms 
 
9.  The People’s Republic of China’s approach to managing water quality, based on targets 
for ambient water quality, is an approach used widely and effectively around the world. Like 
other  comprehensive  approaches  to  managing  water  quality,  ambient  standards  require 
advanced scientific, engineering, and administrative expertise. The HRB management system 
still lacks this as it is still in the early stages of development, although proceeding at a pace at or 
above that in other countries. 
 
10.  Meeting the water quality targets requires a system to manage and control all significant 
emissions. Such a system involves at least three elements: emission permits, monitoring of 
emissions and ambient water quality, and enforcement of permit violations. Each of these 
elements is a part of the HRPCPP, or is being developed.  
E.  Need for the Project 
11.  Hebei's surface-water quality has suffered due to large quantities of untreated urban 
wastewater discharged into receiving waters, and insufficient wastewater treatment facilities. 
Hebei has committed to control water pollution in support of the HRPCPP.  
 
12.  The Project will add about 197 million cubic meters per year of treatment capacity, or 
about 50% of the total treatment capacity in Hebei. In combination with other projects and the 
existing wastewater treatment plants, at least 75% of municipal wastewater will be treated by 
2010, which will significantly improve surface-water quality. The Project will also help strengthen 
the institutional capacity for basin-wide wastewater management through policy reform and 
institutional capacity building.

FINANCIAL PROJECTIONS 
 
A.  Overview 
 
1.   The financial projections have been prepared in accordance with  Guidelines for the 
Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the ADB and 
Framework for the Economic and Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects of 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  The  financial  performance  of  operational  municipal 
sewerage companies (MSCs) has been evaluated and projections made with and without the 
Project.  Where MSCs need to be formed, an opening balance statement has been created and 
projections made from it with and without the Project. A sensitivity analysis has also been 
undertaken  using  five  key  variables:  increase  in  capital  costs,  increase  in  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) costs, decrease in revenue, currency devaluation, and benefits delayed by 
1 year. The results show that these variables will not jeopardize the viability of the Project. 
Further details of the financial projections are in Supplementary Appendix F.  
 
B.  Basis of Estimation 
 
2.   For the financial analysis, constant (2003) prices were used.  The financial projections 
were calculated for 15 years (2003–2017) using current prices. 
 
C.  Operating Costs 
 
3.   Direct O&M costs include repairs and maintenance, personnel, energy costs, chemicals, 
administration, and other expenses. Total direct O&M costs have been estimated in the project 
preparation  technical  assistance  feasibility  studies  and  compared  to  the  actual  operating 
experience of the existing Tangshan wastewater treatment plant and other similar plants in the 
People's Republic of China (PRC). On this basis, the major items and their proportion of direct 
O&M costs are repairs and maintenance (37%), wages (16%), energy (16%), chemicals (2–
10%), and administration (16%).  These proportions are considered reasonable.    
 
4.  Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method and is based on 5% of the 
historical cost of fixed assets (for new assets) and 2% for existing assets to be transferred from 
the municipal government departments. 
 
D.  Revenues 
 
5.  Revenue from wastewater tariffs has been calculated by multiplying the volume of 
wastewater treated by the proposed tariffs for each year. The tariffs will be increased in three 
steps (2004, 2006, and 2008) to ensure that full cost recovery is achieved by 2008, the first year 
of operations. The proposed wastewater tariff in constant prices ranges from CNY0.97 per cubic 
meter (m3) in Tangshan to CNY1.24 per m3 in Zhangjiakou in 2008.  Details of tariffs are shown 
in Appendix 14.

2.  The total project cost is estimated at $165.4 million, which includes base costs, financing

construction period is estimated at 2.5% in the first year and then 4% thereafter for local costs

been estimated in the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) feasibility studies and 
compared to the actual operating experience of the existing Tangshan wastewater treatment 
plant and other similar plants in the People's Republic of China (PRC). On this basis, the major 
items and their proportion of direct O&M costs are repairs and maintenance (37%), wages 
(16%), energy (16%), chemicals (2–10%), and administration (16%).  These proportions are 
considered reasonable. 
 
4.   The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for the Project was calculated over a 25-year 
period on net cash flows. The base-case FIRR of the five project components is 5.0–7.3%,

WACC used is at the minimum rate test level of 4% for all components, as the calculated 
WACCs were below this level. The FIRRs and associated sensitivity tests are in Table A14.1. 
All components are financially sustainable with positive FIRRs for all sensitivity tests.  The 
components are more sensitive to changes in revenues than changes in costs.  
 
5.   It is important to note that even with the devaluation of the yuan by 30% against the 
dollar, components still show a positive FIRR. Risk mitigation measures include the PPTA 
feasibility studies that identified tradable and nontradable components to ensure that foreign 
exchange requirements have not been overestimated.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The economic analysis of the Project is not based on standard benefit-cost analysis, 
since it imposes an unduly restrictive perspective on the Project. Benefit-cost analysis must 
consider all social benefits and costs, covering the entire project scope so that all other factors 
are exogenous to the analysis. In the case of wastewater treatment, benefit-cost analysis is 
appropriate where a regulatory or management regime is not in place, and where the project 
intends to address simple and specific water pollution problems: for example, raw wastewater 
affecting a single large water user downstream. The Project, in contrast, is a small part of the 
greater  plan  to  manage  water  quality  in  the  basin,  so  an  analysis  focusing  only  on  the 
wastewater treatment plants would not reveal the full economic justification or motivation for the 
Project. 
 
2.  The primary aim of the Project is to help Hebei Province meet the legally established 
water quality targets for the Hai River Basin. The economic analysis therefore focused first on 
the goals, to evaluate whether they are reasonable and command public support. Taking the 
goals as given, the economic analysis considered how the goals can be met at the least 
economic cost. 
 
B.  Evaluation of the Water Quality Targets 
 
3.  The wastewater sector analysis in Appendix 2 discusses the water quality targets and 
legal framework. The water quality targets could, in principle, be determined by benefit-cost 
analysis;  if  so,  economic  analysis  of  the  Project  could  rest  on  the  benefit-cost analysis 
conducted in support of the targets. However, they were not set using benefit-cost analysis but 
determined through a consultative process within government, with some consultation with 
external stakeholders. The justification for the targets would be stronger if there were more 
evidence of public participation in water quality target setting. However, it is a technical process 
in which the general public has little interest, and the targets as well as the method of setting 
them are broadly consistent with best international practice. 
 
4.  Despite the limited public participation in target setting, broad public support is evident 
for improving environmental quality in general and water quality in particular. The survey 
conducted for the Project indicated general public support for improved water quality. In the 
project cities, 61% of survey respondents rated “a clean environment and unpolluted rivers” as 
“most important,” and installing a sewerage system was the number-one priority for urban 
improvement1. The analysis of other recent ADB-funded projects in the PRC found similar 
support for water quality management and environmental improvement. 
 
C.  Evaluation of the Plan for Meeting the Water Quality Targets 
 
5.  The plan to meet the goals is embodied mainly in the Hai River Pollution Prevention and 
Control  Plan  (HRPCPP).  Development  of  a  water  quality  management  regime  has  many 
components, and a prioritization process considered all the important economic factors to 
establish the highest priorities, which appear reasonable from an economic perspective.2

7.  The treatment plants in the Project are therefore an integral component in the plan to 
meet the Hai River Basin’s water quality targets. Economic analysis of the project components 
shows that they are designed to achieve least-cost management of wastewater. Three aspects 
in the design are crucial: (i) all significant point sources in the surrounding areas are controlled, 
(ii) all wastewater generators will face the same effluent charge, and (iii) the charge will 
approximate  the  marginal  cost  of  processing  wastewater  at  the  central  treatment  plant. 
According to standard economic theory, these are sufficient to provide economic incentives for 
least-cost management of wastewater across all point sources.4 
 
8.  Although not expressed in monetary terms, clear and important  project benefits will 
accrue to project cities and beyond. Urban residents who will pay the wastewater tariff will 
benefit from improved environmental quality. The wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) will 
benefit downstream surface-water users, although they are difficult to identify and the benefits 
hard to express in monetary terms.   
 
9.  The main uncertainty in the economic analysis is predicting the impact of the WWTPs on 
ambient water quality. The uncertainty is due to the lack of scientific information on the link 
between wastewater treatment and water quality, which cannot be modeled adequately under 
existing conditions. Developing the needed information requires a comprehensive plan that 
takes into account regulation of stream flows and the impact of nonpoint sources and is part of 
the evolving plan to manage water quality. The authorities appear committed to carrying out the 
required long-term programs.

54  Appendix 16 
ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT 
 
A.  Potential Impacts 
1.  The Project's environmental impact is substantially positive, and the benefits greatly 
outweigh the negative impact. The Project will have substantial positive impact on the urban 
environment and surface-water quality in the associated rivers, impoundments, and Bohai Bay. 
With the planned mitigation measures in place, adverse impact on the physical and natural 
environment will be insignificant. The Project will improve the living environment of project area 
residents and contribute appreciably to the Hai River Basin's water pollution control program. 
The Project will (i) safeguard the quality of water supply sources of Beijing and Tianjin, (ii) help 
to create conditions to raise living standards, and (iii) improve public health conditions.  
 
2.  The  potentially  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  short  term:  noise,  vibration,  air 
pollution, runoff, safety hazards, disposal of debris, and localized traffic congestion during 
construction. 
B.  Mitigation Measures 
3.  Appropriate mitigation measures have been incorporated into the selection of locations 
for wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) and sewers, and into the comparison of system 
alternatives.  Each  of  the  five  subprojects  has  adopted  measures  to  minimize  hazards  or 
nuisance, including provision of buffer zones (200–300 meters) and fences, noise and aerosol 
abatement, and contingency plans for accidental wastewater overflows or spills. Processes that 
can accommodate shock loads from ni dustry have been selected. The local environmental 
protection bureau (EPB) in each project city is preparing a plan to control hazardous materials in 
industrial wastewater. 
 
4.  The  Hebei  provincial  government  and  municipal  sewerage  companies  (MSCs)  will 
ensure that the detailed designs of WWTPs adequately address potential effluent and sludge 
reuse issues. Before startup of the WWTPs, measures will be completed to assure collection of 
wastewater  from  major  industrial  dischargers  and  local  tertiary  sewer  networks,  and 
arrangements will be in place for sludge disposal in accordance with national regulations. Each 
municipal government will prepare an industrial pollution control plan in a format acceptable to 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  including  relevant  monitoring  and  enforcement 
arrangements. These plans are to be submitted to ADB by 31 December 2003. 
 
5.  Environmental  protection  measures  for  construction  are  required  as  part  of  the 
engineering  contracts.  Good  practices  such  as  dust  reduction,  provision  of  storm  runoff 
detention ponds, controlled disposal of spoil material, and washing of truck tires before leaving 
the construction site are some environmental protection measures to be adopted in the contract 
specifications. Other stipulations will control construction activities that may produce short-term 
noise,  vibration,  air  pollution,  muddy  runoff,  safety  hazards,  sewage  from  construction 
personnel, solid wastes and debris, spoils, traffic congestion, and silt runoff. 
 
6.  The HPG, project cities, and MSCs will ensure that the project facilities are constructed, 
operated, maintained, and monitored in conformance with all applicable laws and regulations, 
including national and local regulations and standards for environmental protection, health, 
labor, and occupational safety. These include carrying out the environmental mitigation and 
monitoring measures detailed in the approved environmental impact assessments (EIAs) and 
summary EIA for the Project. 
 
7.  Plans for public involvement during construction and operation have been developed, 
including for public participation in monitoring impacts and mitigation measures; evaluation of

environmental,  economic,  and  social  impacts;  and  surveys  of  public  opinion  after  project 
completion.  The plans include several types of public involvement: site visits, workshops, 
investigation of specific issues, and interviews. The plans will be incorporated into the project 
construction and operation management plan. 
C.  Environmental Monitoring  
8.  Local environmental monitoring stations will be responsible for external environmental 
monitoring  during  construction  and  operation.  The  MSC  will  be  responsible  for  internal 
environmental monitoring during operation. Local and provincial EPBs will be responsible for 
supervising the monitoring. The MSCs will be responsible for daily routine monitoring. The 
environmental monitoring results during construction and operation will be submitted to the local 
EPB, Hebei Province Management Office (HPMO), and other responsible agencies. Local EPBs 
and the MSCs will be responsible for supervising implementation of the monitoring program 
and, if necessary, will decide on further mitigation actions during construction and operation. 
Each MSC is responsible for preparing and submitting annual environmental reports. 
 
9.  Each  MSC  will  engage  an  adequate  number  of  full-time personnel and sufficient 
resources to monitor the environmental monitoring program, under guidance of the relevant city 
EPB and Environmental Monitoring Center. Monitoring reports will be provided to the HPMO, 
which will coordinate the preparation of an annual environmental report in a format acceptable 
to ADB. These annual reports will be submitted to ADB, by 31 March each year, until project 
facilities start commercial operation. 
D.  Water Quality Monitoring Network 
10.  The locations and water quality parameters to be measured at water quality monitoring 
stations will be selected as part of the project performance monitoring system, to quantify the 
Project's environmental benefits. For each urban wastewater service area, one monitoring 
station will be located on an urban waterway upstream from the WWTP to assure that much of 
the urban wastewater has been collected and intercepted by the project sewers. A second 
monitoring station will be downstream from the WWTP to quantify the improvements in water 
quality affecting downstream communities and water users within the Hai River Basin and Bohai 
Bay.  Where suitable, the monitored locations will be selected to coincide with the existing 54 
monitoring control sections in Hebei, which are operated by national, provincial, municipal, and 
county EPBs.
